prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The goal of this proposal is to image dust continuum emission for a sample of protoplanetary disks already imaged with the VLA. However, we will take advantage of the correlator versatility, and simultaneously observe 12CO, 13CO, and C18O, in their J=2-1 transition: (1) Basebands 2 and 4 will observe continuum emission with the widest possible BW (1.875 GHz per polarization), to keep the data rate to a minimum. (2) Baseband 1 is split in two windows of 468.8 MHz BW each. The first window observes the continuum with a low data rate. The second window observes 12CO(2-1) with high velocity resolution (0.6 km/s), sufficient to spectrally resolve the few km/s wide lines. (3) Finally, baseband 3 is split into 4 windows of 468.8 MHz BW each, to observe 13CO(2-1) and C18O(2-1) in the same baseband with 1.3 km/s velocity resolution, as well as the continuum in the other two bands. These lines are not critical to the proposal goal , but the correlator versatility allows for its simultaneous observation while keeping the aggregate continuum BW on this baseband to the maximum of 1.875 GHz per polarization.

(1) A single pointing per target is required. The proposed circumstellar disks have spatial extents of about 2", which fits well within the 25" FOV. Note that for MHO1 and MHO2, a single pointing in between these targets suffices, since these two stars are separated by 4" (much less than FOV).
(2) The requested angular resolution is defined to match (or at least be close enough) to the resolution of our existing VLA observations, which have spatial resolutions of 0.18" for MHO 1 and MHO 2; 0.13" for V892Tau and DOTau; 0.11" for RY Tau; 0.08" for DGTau and DGTauB; 0.19" for Haro6-13; and 0.27" for DNTau. Hence, the requested angular resolution of 0.15 is well suited to resolve the emission from these disks at a similar resolution than the VLA.
(3) Measurements in the literature give diameters of few hundreds AU (about 2 at the target distances), and given the largest angular scale that can be imaged in Band 6 is few arcseconds these observations should not suffer from significant spatial filtering. Furthermore, our VLA observations (Figure 1) show that the emission we are interested in is quite compact.

(1) Our sensitivity request is motivated by the brightness temperature sensitivity achieved in our VLA observations: typically we reached an RMS sensitivity of 0.1 K in a 0.2-0.3 beam at a wavelength of 1cm. For the cold outer regions of a protoplanetary disk, we expect the emission to be optically thin with a dust temperature of about 20K. Thus, a brightness temperature sensitivity of 0.07K in these ALMA observations will allow for a detection with SNR=10 of optically thin regions in the outer disk with an optical depth as low as tau=0.03. As the inner disk regions are brighter, warmer, and may even be optically thick, a SNR of 100 or more is expected if an RMS of 0.07 K in the ~0.12-0.15 ALMA beam, with 6.56 GHz of aggregate BW.
(2) Now, the goal of this proposal is to distinguish spatial variations of the dust opacity spectral index "beta. The uncertainty in "beta" is directly proportional to log(lambda1/lambda2)*((1/SNR1)^2 + (1/SNR2)^2)^0.5, where "SNR1" and "SNR2" are the Signal-to-Noise ratio of the two wavelengths (lambda 1 and lambda2) involved in the estimation of "beta". If the SNR of the ALMA observations is between 10 (in the outer disk) and 100 (at the peak of emission), we expect that these observations will improve our "beta" constraints from those obtained from 7mm/1cm VLA observations by 30-50% in the outer disk regions, while in the bright inner disk our constraints in "beta" will improve by an order of magnitude or more.
(3) The expected source properties are not known a priori, mostly due to the lack of observations that match the requested angular resolution at the ALMA wavelengths. Thus, we estimate the peak flux density in the ALMA wavelengths from our VLA 7mm/1cm observations, taking care to subtract the possible contamination from free-free that some young stars possess at the center of their disk. We also corrected for beam dilution since the synthesized beams of ALMA and VLA are not identical. This results all of our targets detected with signal-to-noise ratios larger than 90.
(4) The focus of this proposal is dust continuum observations, however, simultaneous observation of various spectral lines (12CO, 13CO, and C18O in the J=(2-1) transition) is possible thanks to the correlator versatility. Thus, we expect to detect any of these lines at more than ~4sigma if they have peak fluxes of 20mJy or brighter.

The goal of this proposal is to image dust continuum emission for a sample of protoplanetary disks already imaged with the VLA. However, we will take advantage of the correlator versatility, and simultaneously observe 12CO, 13CO, and C18O, in their J=2-1 transition: (1) Basebands 2 and 4 will observe continuum emission with the widest possible BW (1.875 GHz per polarization), to keep the data rate to a minimum. (2) Baseband 1 is split in two windows of 468.8 MHz BW each. The first window observes the continuum with a low data rate. The second window observes 12CO(2-1) with high velocity resolution (0.6 km/s), sufficient to spectrally resolve the few km/s wide lines. (3) Finally, baseband 3 is split into 4 windows of 468.8 MHz BW each, to observe 13CO(2-1) and C18O(2-1) in the same baseband with 1.3 km/s velocity resolution, as well as the continuum in the other two bands. These lines are not critical to the proposal goal , but the correlator versatility allows for its simultaneous observation while keeping the aggregate continuum BW on this baseband to the maximum of 1.875 GHz per polarization.

(1) A single pointing per target is required. The proposed circumstellar disks have spatial extents of a few arcsec, which fits well within the 25" FOV.
(2) The requested angular resolution is defined to match (or at least be close enough) to the resolution of our existing VLA observations, which have spatial resolutions of 0.19" for DMTau and 0.25" for UXTau. Hence, the requested angular resolution of 0.14" is well suited to resolve the emission from these disks at a similar or better resolution than the VLA.
(3) Measurements in the literature give diameters of few hundreds AU (about 2 at the target distances), and given the largest angular scale that can be imaged in Band 6 is few arcseconds these observations should not suffer from significant spatial filtering. Furthermore, our VLA observations (Figure 1) show that the emission we are interested in is quite compact.

(1) Our sensitivity request is motivated by the brightness temperature sensitivity achieved in our VLA observations: typically we reached an RMS sensitivity of 0.1 K in a 0.2-0.3 beam at a wavelength of 1cm. For the cold outer regions of a protoplanetary disk, we expect the emission to be optically thin with a dust temperature of about 20K. Thus, a brightness temperature sensitivity of 0.07K in these ALMA observations will allow for a detection with SNR=10 of optically thin regions in the outer disk with an optical depth as low as tau=0.03. As the inner disk regions are brighter, warmer, and may even be optically thick, a SNR of 100 or more is expected if an RMS of 0.07 K in the ~0.12-0.15 ALMA beam, with 6.56 GHz of aggregate BW.
(2) Now, the goal of this proposal is to distinguish spatial variations of the dust opacity spectral index "beta. The uncertainty in "beta" is directly proportional to log(lambda1/lambda2)*((1/SNR1)^2 + (1/SNR2)^2)^0.5, where "SNR1" and "SNR2" are the Signal-to-Noise ratio of the two wavelengths (lambda 1 and lambda2) involved in the estimation of "beta". If the SNR of the ALMA observations is between 10 (in the outer disk) and 100 (at the peak of emission), we expect that these observations will improve our "beta" constraints from those obtained from 7mm/1cm VLA observations by 30-50% in the outer disk regions, while in the bright inner disk our constraints in "beta" will improve by an order of magnitude or more.
(3) The expected source properties are not known a priori, mostly due to the lack of observations that match the requested angular resolution at the ALMA wavelengths. Thus, we estimate the peak flux density in the ALMA wavelengths from our VLA 7mm/1cm observations, taking care to subtract the possible contamination from free-free that some young stars possess at the center of their disk. We also corrected for beam dilution since the synthesized beams of ALMA and VLA are not identical. This results all of our targets detected with signal-to-noise ratios larger than 80.
(4) The focus of this proposal is dust continuum observations, however, simultaneous observation of various spectral lines (12CO, 13CO, and C18O in the J=(2-1) transition) is possible thanks to the correlator versatility. Thus, we expect to detect any of these lines at more than ~5sigma if they have peak fluxes of 20mJy or brighter.

The goal of this proposal is to image dust continuum emission for a sample of protoplanetary disks already imaged with the VLA. However, we will take advantage of the correlator versatility, and simultaneously observe 12CO, 13CO, and C18O, in their J=2-1 transition: (1) Basebands 2 and 4 will observe continuum emission with the widest possible BW (1.875 GHz per polarization), to keep the data rate to a minimum. (2) Baseband 1 is split in two windows of 468.8 MHz BW each. The first window observes the continuum with a low data rate. The second window observes 12CO(2-1) with high velocity resolution (0.6 km/s), sufficient to spectrally resolve the few km/s wide lines. (3) Finally, baseband 3 is split into 4 windows of 468.8 MHz BW each, to observe 13CO(2-1) and C18O(2-1) in the same baseband with 1.3 km/s velocity resolution, as well as the continuum in the other two bands. These lines are not critical to the proposal goal , but the correlator versatility allows for its simultaneous observation while keeping the aggregate continuum BW on this baseband to the maximum of 1.875 GHz per polarization.

(1) A single pointing per target is required. The proposed circumstellar disks have spatial extents of a few arcsec, which fits well within the 25" FOV.
(2) The requested angular resolution is defined to match (or at least be close enough) to the resolution of our existing VLA observations, which have spatial resolutions of 0.11" for MWC480 and 0.33" for UYAur. Hence, the requested angular resolution of 0.15" is well suited to resolve the emission from these disks at a similar or better resolution than the VLA.
(3) Measurements in the literature give diameters of few hundreds AU (about 2 at the target distances), and given the largest angular scale that can be imaged in Band 6 is few arcseconds these observations should not suffer from significant spatial filtering. Furthermore, our VLA observations (Figure 1) show that the emission we are interested in is quite compact.

(1) Our sensitivity request is motivated by the brightness temperature sensitivity achieved in our VLA observations: typically we reached an RMS sensitivity of 0.1 K in a 0.2-0.3 beam at a wavelength of 1cm. Thus, a brightness temperature sensitivity of 0.07K in these ALMA observations will allow for a detection with SNR=10 of optically thin regions in the outer disk with an optical depth as low as tau=0.03. As the inner disk regions are brighter, warmer, and may even be optically thick, a SNR of 100 or more is expected if an RMS of 0.07 K in the ~0.12-0.15 ALMA beam, with 6.56 GHz of aggregate BW.
(2) Now, the goal of this proposal is to distinguish spatial variations of the dust opacity spectral index "beta. The uncertainty in "beta" is directly proportional to log(lambda1/lambda2)*((1/SNR1)^2 + (1/SNR2)^2)^0.5, where "SNR1" and "SNR2" are the Signal-to-Noise ratio of the two wavelengths (lambda 1 and lambda2) involved in the estimation of "beta". If the SNR of the ALMA observations is between 10 (in the outer disk) and 100 (at the peak of emission), we expect that these observations will improve our "beta" constraints from those obtained from 7mm/1cm VLA observations by 30-50% in the outer disk regions, while in the bright inner disk our constraints in "beta" will improve by an order of magnitude or more.
(3) The expected source properties are not known a priori, mostly due to the lack of observations that match the requested angular resolution at the ALMA wavelengths. Thus, we estimate the peak flux density in the ALMA wavelengths from our VLA 7mm/1cm observations, taking care to subtract the possible contamination from free-free that some young stars possess at the center of their disk. We also corrected for beam dilution since the synthesized beams of ALMA and VLA are not identical. This results all of our targets detected with signal-to-noise ratios larger than ~250.
(4) The focus of this proposal is dust continuum observations, however, simultaneous observation of various spectral lines (12CO, 13CO, and C18O in the J=(2-1) transition) is possible thanks to the correlator versatility. Thus, we expect to detect any of these lines at more than ~4sigma if they have peak fluxes of 20mJy or brighter.

(1) A single pointing per target is required. The proposed circumstellar disks have spatial extents of a few arcsec, which fits well within the 25" FOV.
(2) The requested angular resolution is defined to match (or at least be close enough) to the resolution of our existing VLA observations, which have spatial resolutions of 0.12" for HD98800. Hence, the requested angular resolution of 0.12" is well suited to resolve the emission from these disks at the same resolution than the VLA.

Furthermore, our VLA observations (Figure 1) show that the emission we are interested in is quite compact.

Thus, we expect to detect any of these lines at more than ~5sigma if they have peak fluxes of 16mJy or brighter.

(1) A single pointing per target is required. The proposed circumstellar disks have spatial extents of a few arcsec, which fits well within the 25" FOV.
(2) The requested angular resolution is defined to match (or at least be close enough) to the resolution of our existing VLA observations, which have spatial resolutions of 0.13 for HD142666; 0.14 for EL24; 0.15 for EL27; 0.16 for GSS26; 0.17 for IRS51; 0.19 for SR24; and 0.24 for WSB60. Hence, the requested angular resolution of 0.12 is well suited to resolve the emission from these disks at a similar resolution than the VLA.

Thus, a brightness temperature sensitivity of 0.07K in these ALMA observations will allow for a detection with SNR=10 of optically thin regions in the outer disk with an optical depth as low as tau=0.03. The goal of this proposal is to image dust continuum emission for a sample of protoplanetary disks already imaged with the VLA. However, we will take advantage of the correlator versatility, and simultaneously observe 13CO, and C18O in their J=1-0 transition:
(1) Basebands 1,2 and 3 will observe continuum emission with the widest possible BW (1.875 GHz per polarization), to keep the data rate to a minimum.
(2) Baseband 4 BW is kept as wide as possible (1.875 GHz per polarization) but with good velocity resolution (2.7 km/s) to spectrally resolve in a few channels the lines of a few km/s width.

(1) A single pointing per target is required. The proposed circumstellar disks have spatial extents of about 2", which fits well within the 53" FOV. Note that for MHO1 and MHO2, a single pointing in between these targets suffices, since these two stars are separated by 4" (much less than FOV).
(2) The requested angular resolution is defined to match (or at least be close enough) to the resolution of our existing VLA observations, which have spatial resolutions of 0.18" for MHO 1 and MHO 2; 0.13" for V892Tau and DOTau; 0.11" for RY Tau; 0.08" for DGTau and DGTauB; 0.19" for Haro6-13; and 0.27" for DNTau. Hence, the requested angular resolution of 0.3" is well suited to resolve the emission from these disks at a similar resolution than the VLA.
(3) Measurements in the literature give diameters of few hundreds AU (about 2 at the target distances), and given the largest angular scale that can be imaged in Band 3 is several arcseconds these observations should not suffer from significant spatial filtering. Furthermore, our VLA observations (Figure 1) show that the emission we are interested in is quite compact.

(1) Our sensitivity request is motivated by the brightness temperature sensitivity achieved in our VLA observations: typically we reached an RMS sensitivity of 0.1 K in a 0.2?-0.3? beam at a wavelength of 1cm. For the cold outer regions of a protoplanetary disk, we expect the emission to be optically thin with a dust temperature of about 20K. Thus, a brightness temperature sensitivity of 0.06K in these ALMA observations will allow for a detection with SNR=10 of optically thin regions in the outer disk with an optical depth as low as tau=0.03. As the inner disk regions are brighter, warmer, and may even be optically thick, a SNR of 80 or more is expected if an RMS of 0.06 K in the ~0.25?-0.32? ALMA beam, with 7.5 GHz of aggregate BW.
(2) Now, the goal of this proposal is to distinguish spatial variations of the dust opacity spectral index "beta?. The uncertainty in "beta" is directly proportional to log(lambda1/lambda2)*((1/SNR1)^2 + (1/SNR2)^2)^0.5, where "SNR1" and "SNR2" are the Signal-to-Noise ratio of the two wavelengths (lambda 1 and lambda2) involved in the estimation of "beta". If the SNR of the ALMA observations is between 10 (in the outer disk) and 100 (at the peak of emission), we expect that these observations will improve our "beta" constraints from those obtained from 7mm/1cm VLA observations by 30-50% in the outer disk regions, while in the bright inner disk our constraints in "beta" will improve by an order of magnitude or more.
(3) The expected source properties are not known a priori, mostly due to the lack of observations that match the requested angular resolution at the ALMA wavelengths. Thus, we estimate the peak flux density in the ALMA wavelengths from our VLA 7mm/1cm observations, taking care to subtract the possible contamination from free-free that some young stars possess at the center of their disk. We also corrected for beam dilution since the synthesized beams of ALMA and VLA are not identical. This results all of our targets detected with signal-to-noise ratios larger than 70.
(4) The focus of this proposal is dust continuum observations, however, simultaneous observation of two spectral lines (13CO and C18O in the J=(1-0) transition) is possible thanks to the correlator versatility. Thus, we expect to detect any of these lines at more than ~5sigma if they have peak fluxes of 28mJy or brighter.

The goal of this proposal is to image dust continuum emission for a sample of protoplanetary disks already imaged with the VLA. However, we will take advantage of the correlator versatility, and simultaneously observe 13CO, and C18O in their J=1-0 transition:
(1) Basebands 1,2 and 3 will observe continuum emission with the widest possible BW (1.875 GHz per polarization), to keep the data rate to a minimum.
(2) Baseband 4 BW is kept as wide as possible (1.875 GHz per polarization) but with good velocity resolution (2.7 km/s) to spectrally resolve in a few channels the lines of a few km/s width.

(1) A single pointing per target is required. The proposed circumstellar disks have spatial extents of a few arcsec, which fits well within the 53" FOV.
(2) The requested angular resolution is defined to match (or at least be close enough) to the resolution of our existing VLA observations, which have spatial resolutions of 0.19" for DMTau and 0.25" for UXTau. Hence, the requested angular resolution of 0.29" is well suited to resolve the emission from these disks at a similar or better resolution than the VLA.

Furthermore, our VLA observations (Figure 1) show that the emission we are interested in is quite compact.

For the cold outer regions of a protoplanetary disk, we expect the emission to be optically thin with a dust temperature of about 20K. As the inner disk regions are brighter, warmer, and may even be optically thick, a SNR of 80 or more is expected if an RMS of 0.06 K in the ~0.25?-0.32? ALMA beam, with 7.5 GHz of aggregate BW.
(2) Now, the goal of this proposal is to distinguish spatial variations of the dust opacity spectral index "beta?. The uncertainty in "beta" is directly proportional to log(lambda1/lambda2)*((1/SNR1)^2 + (1/SNR2)^2)^0.5, where "SNR1" and "SNR2" are the Signal-to-Noise ratio of the two wavelengths (lambda 1 and lambda2) involved in the estimation of "beta". If the SNR of the ALMA observations is between 10 (in the outer disk) and 100 (at the peak of emission), we expect that these observations will improve our "beta" constraints from those obtained from 7mm/1cm VLA observations by 30-50% in the outer disk regions, while in the bright inner disk our constraints in "beta" will improve by an order of magnitude or more.
(3) The expected source properties are not known a priori, mostly due to the lack of observations that match the requested angular resolution at the ALMA wavelengths. Thus, we estimate the peak flux density in the ALMA wavelengths from our VLA 7mm/1cm observations, taking care to subtract the possible contamination from free-free that some young stars possess at the center of their disk. We also corrected for beam dilution since the synthesized beams of ALMA and VLA are not identical. This results all of our targets detected with signal-to-noise ratios larger than 60.
(4) The focus of this proposal is dust continuum observations, however, simultaneous observation of two spectral lines (13CO and C18O in the J=(1-0) transition) is possible thanks to the correlator versatility. Thus, we expect to detect any of these lines at more than ~5sigma if they have peak fluxes of 28mJy or brighter.

The goal of this proposal is to image dust continuum emission for a sample of protoplanetary disks already imaged with the VLA. However, we will take advantage of the correlator versatility, and simultaneously observe 13CO, and C18O in their J=1-0 transition:
(1) Basebands 1,2 and 3 will observe continuum emission with the widest possible BW (1.875 GHz per polarization), to keep the data rate to a minimum.
(2) Baseband 4 BW is kept as wide as possible (1.875 GHz per polarization) but with good velocity resolution (2.7 km/s) to spectrally resolve in a few channels the lines of a few km/s width.

(1) A single pointing per target is required. The proposed circumstellar disks have spatial extents of a few arcsec, which fits well within the 53" FOV.
(2) The requested angular resolution is defined to match (or at least be close enough) to the resolution of our existing VLA observations, which have spatial resolutions of 0.11" for MWC480 and 0.33" for UYAur. Hence, the requested angular resolution of 0.32" is well suited to resolve the emission from these disks at a similar or better resolution than the VLA.
(3) Measurements in the literature give diameters of few hundreds AU (about 2 at the target distances), and given the largest angular scale that can be imaged in Band 3 is several arcseconds these observations should not suffer from significant spatial filtering. Furthermore, our VLA observations (Figure 1) show that the emission we are interested in is quite compact.

(1) Our sensitivity request is motivated by the brightness temperature sensitivity achieved in our VLA observations: typically we reached an RMS sensitivity of 0.1 K in a 0.2?-0.3? beam at a wavelength of 1cm. For the cold outer regions of a protoplanetary disk, we expect the emission to be optically thin with a dust temperature of about 20K. Thus, a brightness temperature sensitivity of 0.06K in these ALMA observations will allow for a detection with SNR=10 of optically thin regions in the outer disk with an optical depth as low as tau=0.03. As the inner disk regions are brighter, warmer, and may even be optically thick, a SNR of 80 or more is expected if an RMS of 0.06 K in the ~0.25?-0.32? ALMA beam, with 7.5 GHz of aggregate BW.
(2) Now, the goal of this proposal is to distinguish spatial variations of the dust opacity spectral index "beta?. The uncertainty in "beta" is directly proportional to log(lambda1/lambda2)*((1/SNR1)^2 + (1/SNR2)^2)^0.5, where "SNR1" and "SNR2" are the Signal-to-Noise ratio of the two wavelengths (lambda 1 and lambda2) involved in the estimation of "beta". (3) The expected source properties are not known a priori, mostly due to the lack of observations that match the requested angular resolution at the ALMA wavelengths. Thus, we estimate the peak flux density in the ALMA wavelengths from our VLA 7mm/1cm observations, taking care to subtract the possible contamination from free-free that some young stars possess at the center of their disk. We also corrected for beam dilution since the synthesized beams of ALMA and VLA are not identical. This results all of our targets detected with signal-to-noise ratios larger than 180.
(4) The focus of this proposal is dust continuum observations, however, simultaneous observation of two spectral lines (13CO and C18O in the J=(1-0) transition) is possible thanks to the correlator versatility. Thus, we expect to detect any of these lines at more than ~5sigma if they have peak fluxes of 32mJy or brighter.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
The first step toward forming planets is the growth of submicron-sized grains into centimeter-sized particles, inside the circumstellar disks that orbit young stars in formation. The long-wavelength emission from large dust is the last observable link in the growth chain from interstellar dust grains to fully fledged planets. Thus, observations of this phase provide crucial constraints to theories of early planetesimal growth and of the transport and evolution of dust particles.
In this proposal we request ALMA observations at 1.3 mm and 2.7 mm, that when combined with our existing 0.7 - 1 cm spatially resolved observations from the VLA, will determine where in the disk are dust grains preferentially growing. With careful characterization of the disk thermal and density structure we can determine the dust optical depth and constrain the dust emissivity index throughout the disk. These ALMA observations will establish if spatial variations of grain growth occur in nature, as it is expected from several theoretical scenarios, such as particle trapping at pressure maxima arising from vortices, turbulence, or Rossby-wave instabilities.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system
